sourcesContent:
import React, { useEffect, useRef, useState } from 'react';
import {
  Box,
  Container,
  Tabs,
  TabList,
  Tab,
  TabPanels,
  TabPanel,
  Heading,
  Text,
  Link,
  VStack,
  UnorderedList,
  ListItem,
  useColorModeValue,
  HStack,
  Select,
  Checkbox,
  RadioGroup,
  Radio,
  Stack,
} from '@chakra-ui/react';
import L from 'leaflet';
import 'leaflet/dist/leaflet.css';

// Complete data constants with coordinates
const countryCoordinates = {
  USA: [37.0902, -95.7129],
  CHN: [35.8617, 104.1954],
  GBR: [55.3781, -3.4360],

// Helper functions
const getReadinessColor = (score) => {
  if (score === null || score === undefined) return '#CCCCCC';
  // Readiness scores in our data range from ~68 to ~87
  const normalized = Math.max(0, Math.min(1, (score - 65) / (90 - 65)));
  if (normalized < 0.5) {
    // Red to Yellow
    return `rgb(255, ${Math.round(255 * (normalized * 2))}, 0)`;
  } else {
    // Yellow to Green
    return `rgb(${Math.round(255 * (2 - normalized * 2))}, 255, 0)`;
  }
};

const getBillsColor = (mentions) => {
  if (mentions === null || mentions === undefined) return '#CCCCCC';
  // Bills mentions in our data range from 0 to 18
  if (mentions === 0) return '#EFF3FF';
  if (mentions <= 3) return '#C6DBEF';
  if (mentions <= 7) return '#9ECAE1';
  if (mentions <= 11) return '#6BAED6';
  if (mentions <= 15) return '#3182BD';
  return '#08519C';
};

const getInvestmentColor = (investment) => {
  if (!investment) return '#CCCCCC';
  // Investment amounts range from ~7,000M to ~328,000M
  if (investment >= 100000) return '#00C851';
  if (investment >= 25000) return '#33B679';
  if (investment >= 15000) return '#66A4A1';
  if (investment >= 10000) return '#9991C9';
  if (investment >= 5000) return '#CC7EF1';
  return '#FF6BF1';
};

const getPopulationRadius = (population) => {
  if (!population) return 0;
  return Math.sqrt(population) * 0.3;
};

const TabContent = () => {
  const mapRef = useRef(null);
  const geojsonLayerRef = useRef(null);
  const [selectedMetric, setSelectedMetric] = useState('Readiness');
  const [showPopulation, setShowPopulation] = useState(false);
  const bgColor = useColorModeValue('white', 'gray.800');
  const borderColor = useColorModeValue('gray.200', 'gray.600');

  useEffect(() => {
    // Ensure the map container exists and is mounted
    if (!mapRef.current) return;

    // Create a variable to store the map instance
    let map = null;

    // Create lookup maps for efficient data access
    const readinessLookup = {};
    const billsLookup = {};
    const investmentLookup = {};
    
    // Populate lookup maps
    console.log('Initializing data lookups...');
    readinessData.forEach(item => {
      const keyForLookup = item.iso_a3;
      const valueForLookup = item.score;
      console.log(`Adding to readinessLookup: Key=${keyForLookup}, Value=${valueForLookup}`);
      readinessLookup[keyForLookup] = valueForLookup;
    });
    
    aiBillsData.forEach(item => {
      const keyForLookup = item.iso_a3;
      const valueForLookup = item.mentions;
      console.log(`Adding to billsLookup: Key=${keyForLookup}, Value=${valueForLookup}`);
      billsLookup[keyForLookup] = valueForLookup;
    });
    
    investmentData.forEach(item => {
      const keyForLookup = item.iso_a3;
      const valueForLookup = item.investment;
      console.log(`Adding to investmentLookup: Key=${keyForLookup}, Value=${valueForLookup}`);
      investmentLookup[keyForLookup] = valueForLookup;
    });

    console.log('Data lookups created:', {
      readinessCount: Object.keys(readinessLookup).length,
      billsCount: Object.keys(billsLookup).length,
      investmentCount: Object.keys(investmentLookup).length
    });

    const updateMap = (geojsonData) => {
      // Remove existing GeoJSON layer if it exists
      if (geojsonLayerRef.current) {
        geojsonLayerRef.current.remove();
      }

      // Create and add the new GeoJSON layer
      geojsonLayerRef.current = L.geoJSON(geojsonData, {
        style: (feature) => {
          const countryCode = feature.properties['ISO3166-1-Alpha-3'];
          let fillColor = '#CCCCCC';
          
          if (selectedMetric === 'Readiness' && readinessLookup[countryCode] !== undefined) {
            fillColor = getReadinessColor(readinessLookup[countryCode]);
          } else if (selectedMetric === 'Bills' && billsLookup[countryCode] !== undefined) {
            fillColor = getBillsColor(billsLookup[countryCode]);
          } else if (selectedMetric === 'Investment' && investmentLookup[countryCode] !== undefined) {
            fillColor = getInvestmentColor(investmentLookup[countryCode]);
          }
          
          return {
            fillColor,
            weight: 1,
            opacity: 1,
            color: 'white',
            fillOpacity: 0.7
          };
        },
        onEachFeature: (feature, layer) => {
          // Log 1: See all properties for this feature
          console.log("Processing feature properties:", feature.properties);

          const countryCode = feature.properties['ISO3166-1-Alpha-3'];
          const countryName = feature.properties.ADMIN || feature.properties.name;

          // Log 2: Verify the extracted country code
          console.log(`Processing country: ${countryName} (${countryCode})`);

          // Check if countryCode was successfully extracted before trying to use it
          if (countryCode) {
            const readinessScore = readinessLookup[countryCode];
            const billsMentions = billsLookup[countryCode];
            const investmentAmount = investmentLookup[countryCode];

            // Log 3: See what data was found (or not found) in the lookups
            console.log(`Available data for ${countryCode}:`, {
              readiness: readinessScore,
              bills: billsMentions,
              investment: investmentAmount
            });

            let popupContent = `<strong>${countryName}</strong><br>`;
            let hasData = false;

            if (readinessScore !== undefined) {
              popupContent += `AI Readiness Score: ${readinessScore.toFixed(2)}<br>`;
              hasData = true;
            }

            if (billsMentions !== undefined) {
              popupContent += `Legislative Mentions: ${billsMentions}<br>`;
              hasData = true;
            }

            if (investmentAmount !== undefined) {
              // Consider adding a check here too if investmentAmount can sometimes be null but not undefined
              popupContent += `AI Investment: $${investmentAmount ? investmentAmount.toLocaleString() : 'N/A'}M<br>`; // Added check for null/0
              hasData = true;
            }

            if (!hasData) {
              popupContent += 'No data available for this country';
            }

            layer.bindPopup(popupContent);

          } else {
            // Log 4: If countryCode couldn't be found in properties
            console.log(`Could not find country code for feature: ${countryName}`);
            layer.bindPopup(`<strong>${countryName}</strong><br>Country code missing.`);
          }
        }
      }).addTo(map);
    };

    // Small delay to ensure DOM is ready
    const initMap = setTimeout(() => {
      try {
        // Initialize map only if it hasn't been created yet
        if (!map) {
          map = L.map(mapRef.current, {
            center: [20, 0],
            zoom: 2,
            minZoom: 2,
            maxZoom: 6
          });
          
          // Add tile layer
          L.tileLayer('https://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png', {
            attribution: '© OpenStreetMap contributors'
          }).addTo(map);
        }

        // Fetch GeoJSON data and update map
        fetch('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/datasets/geo-countries/master/data/countries.geojson')
          .then(response => {
            if (!response.ok) {
              throw new Error('Network response was not ok');
            }
            return response.json();
          })
          .then(data => {
            console.log('GeoJSON data loaded, features count:', data.features.length);
            updateMap(data);
          })
          .catch(error => {
            console.error('Error loading or processing GeoJSON:', error);
          });

      } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error initializing map:', error);
      }
    }, 100);

    // Cleanup function
    return () => {
      clearTimeout(initMap);
      if (geojsonLayerRef.current) {
        geojsonLayerRef.current.remove();
      }
      if (map) {
        map.remove();
      }
    };
  }, [selectedMetric]);

  return (
    <Box bg={bgColor} minH="100vh" py={8}>
      <Container maxW="container.xl">
        <Tabs isLazy variant="enclosed" colorScheme="blue">
          <TabList mb="1em" overflowX="auto" flexWrap="nowrap">
            <Tab>Homepage</Tab>
            <Tab>What Is AI Red Teaming - and Why Access Matters</Tab>
            <Tab>Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming</Tab>
            <Tab>Enabling Participation</Tab>
            <Tab>Domain-Specific Governance</Tab>
            <Tab>Global Coordination</Tab>
            <Tab>Resources</Tab>
            <Tab>References</Tab>
          </TabList>

          <TabPanels>
            {/* Homepage Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h2" size="xl" mb={4}>
                  Bridging the Global AI Divide: Towards Inclusive Safety
                </Heading>

                {/* Map Controls */}
                <Box mb={4}>
                  <HStack spacing={8} mb={4}>
                    <RadioGroup value={selectedMetric} onChange={setSelectedMetric}>
                      <Stack direction="row">
                        <Radio value="Readiness">AI Readiness</Radio>
                        <Radio value="Investment">AI Investment</Radio>
                        <Radio value="Bills">Legislative Mentions</Radio>
                      </Stack>
                    </RadioGroup>
                    <Checkbox
                      isChecked={showPopulation}
                      onChange={(e) => setShowPopulation(e.target.checked)}
                    >
                      Show Population Overlay
                    </Checkbox>
                  </HStack>
                </Box>

                {/* Map Container */}
                <Box
                  ref={mapRef}
                  h="70vh"
                  w="100%"
                  position="relative"
                  borderRadius="lg"
                  overflow="hidden"
                  border="1px solid"
                  borderColor={borderColor}
                  mb={4}
                  mx="auto"
                  sx={{
                    '.leaflet-container': {
                      width: '100%',
                      height: '100%'
                    }
                  }}
                />

                {/* Legend */}
                <Box p={4} bg={useColorModeValue('gray.50', 'gray.700')} borderRadius="lg">
                  <Heading as="h3" size="sm" mb={2}>Legend</Heading>
                  <HStack spacing={4}>
                    <Box>
                      <Box w="20px" h="20px" bg="#ff4444" display="inline-block" mr={2} />
                      {selectedMetric === 'Readiness' ? 'Low Readiness' : 
                       selectedMetric === 'Investment' ? 'Low Investment' : 'Few Mentions'}
                    </Box>
                    <Box>
                      <Box w="20px" h="20px" bg="#ffbb33" display="inline-block" mr={2} />
                      {selectedMetric === 'Readiness' ? 'Medium Readiness' : 
                       selectedMetric === 'Investment' ? 'Medium Investment' : 'Some Mentions'}
                    </Box>
                    <Box>
                      <Box w="20px" h="20px" bg="#00C851" display="inline-block" mr={2} />
                      {selectedMetric === 'Readiness' ? 'High Readiness' : 
                       selectedMetric === 'Investment' ? 'High Investment' : 'Many Mentions'}
                    </Box>
                    <Box>
                      <Box w="20px" h="20px" bg="#cccccc" display="inline-block" mr={2} />
                      No Data
                    </Box>
                    {showPopulation && (
                      <Box>
                        <Box
                          w="20px"
                          h="20px"
                          borderRadius="full"
                          bg="#4A90E2"
                          opacity={0.4}
                          border="1px solid #2171C7"
                          display="inline-block"
                          mr={2}
                        />
                        Population
                      </Box>
                    )}
                  </HStack>
                </Box>

                <Text mb={3}>
                  Artificial intelligence is advancing at breakneck speed, yet its development and benefits are dramatically concentrated. While AI innovation flourishes primarily in a few Global North countries, its impacts reverberate globally, touching populations who often have little influence over its design or deployment.
                </Text>
                <Text mb={3}>
                  This disconnect creates a stark reality: projections estimate that by 2030, North America, Europe, and China will capture <Link href="https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/issues/analytics/assets/pwc-ai-analysis-sizing-the-prize-report.pdf" isExternal color="blue.500">84% of AI's economic gains</Link>, while regions like Africa, Oceania, and the rest of Asia combined may see only 8%. Such trajectories threaten to <Link href="https://foreignpolicy.com/2024/12/17/ai-global-south-inequality/" isExternal color="blue.500">deepen global inequality</Link>, as leading AI nations gain outsized advantages. Furthermore, without inclusive governance, dominant cultural and economic perspectives risk imposing 'one-size-fits-all' AI values and policies ill-suited to diverse local contexts.
                </Text>
                <Text mb={3}>
                  The data often used to train AI reflects this imbalance. Large language models, typically trained on internet data, <Link href="https://www.weforum.org/stories/2024/09/ai-linguistic-diversity-gap-missed-opportunity/" isExternal color="blue.500">underrepresent the world's linguistic diversity; none of the top 34 internet languages are African, and most models cover only about 100 of over 7,000 global languages</Link>. This occurs despite Africa being home to nearly 19% of the world's population. Consequently, even advanced AI models exhibit <Link href="https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2402.02680" isExternal color="blue.500">geographic biases</Link> favoring high-income regions and can perpetuate harmful stereotypes, such as rating African residents less attractive than Europeans.
                </Text>
                <Text mb={3}>
                  The stakes are high. This isn't merely about representation in development teams; it's about the real-world consequences when widely used AI systems reflect narrow perspectives. Models trained primarily on Western data can malfunction or misdiagnose when applied elsewhere – for instance, a health AI accurate for European patients <Link href="https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-031-08215-3" isExternal color="blue.500">has shown significant errors when used with African patients</Link>, highlighting how data and design choices impact lives.
                </Text>
                <Text mb={3}>
                  This project confronts this governance gap by focusing on a critical lever for more democratic AI oversight: AI red teaming. By deliberately probing AI systems for vulnerabilities, biases, and unexpected failure modes, we can uncover risks missed by internal teams. Our goal is to identify pathways toward inclusive AI security governance – frameworks that embed global perspectives and promote equity, safety, and accountability across all linguistic and geographic divides.
                </Text>
                <Text as="i" mt={4}>
                  For detailed sources and further reading, please see the References and Resources section.
                </Text>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* What Is AI Red Teaming - and Why Access Matters Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Text>
                  AI red teaming refers to the practice of probing AI systems for vulnerabilities, biases, and failure modes by adopting an adversarial mindset. Red teaming has its roots in cybersecurity and the military, but has become an integral part of AI development at major labs, where internal red teams try to identify flaws in large models. (<Link href="https://www.humane-intelligence.org/grt" isExternal color="blue.500">Storchan et al., 2024</Link>) In practice, red teamers may test for jailbreaks, harmful content generation, biased outputs, privacy leaks, or the ability of a model to follow dangerous instructions. The process often involves generating prompts that are specifically engineered to bypass safeguards, eliciting model behavior that violates safety or alignment goals. Red teaming can be manual—done by expert analysts—or automated, using tools to generate adversarial prompts at scale. The results of red teaming exercises inform the design of mitigation strategies such as model fine-tuning, reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), or stronger content filters. In many labs, red teaming is an iterative process embedded across stages of model evaluation and release, and is increasingly supported by interdisciplinary teams with expertise in security, linguistics, law, and social science. (<Link href="https://ai.meta.com/research/publications/mart-improving-llm-safety-with-multi-round-automatic-red-teaming/" isExternal color="blue.500">Meta</Link>, <Link href="https://openai.com/index/advancing-red-teaming-with-people-and-ai/" isExternal color="blue.500">OpenAI</Link>, <Link href="https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/anthropics-comprehensive-approach-red-teaming-ai-models-ajay-naha-qk6xc" isExternal color="blue.500">Anthropic</Link>, 2024) Inclusive red teaming and development bring diverse perspectives to the table, leading to more robust and fair AI systems.
                </Text>
                <Text>
                  There are many concrete examples of how lack of inclusion has caused harm – and how broader input can add value:
                </Text>
                <UnorderedList spacing={3}>
                  <ListItem>
                    <Text fontWeight="bold">Linguistic & Geographic Bias:</Text> AI systems often perform poorly for languages or communities absent in training data. Independent researchers have found that large language models (trained mostly on English and European data) carry "geographic bias" – for instance, systematically underrating content related to African countries on subjective qualities like "intelligence" or "morality." (<Link href="https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2402.02680" isExternal color="blue.500">Manvi et al., 2024</Link>) Generative AI tools also struggle with many low-resource languages, leading to errors and the exclusion of non-English speakers. These biases can amplify inequality (e.g. an AI assistant that works well in English but garbles Swahili is far less useful to African users). Global inclusion in red teaming ensures testers who speak diverse languages and come from varied regions can identify these blind spots early. Indeed, when multilingual teams have stress-tested AI models, they uncovered critical flaws in how the AI handled languages like Bengali and Swahili that the original developers missed (<Link href="https://knightcolumbia.org/blog/a-safe-harbor-for-ai-evaluation-and-red-teaming#:~:text=While%20many%20types%20of%20testing,bias%2C%20copyright%2C%20and%20other%20issues" isExternal color="blue.500">related research context</Link>).
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    <Text fontWeight="bold">Health & Safety Risks (Misdiagnoses):</Text> If AI applications (like medical diagnosis tools) are developed using homogenous data, they can be dangerously unreliable for underrepresented groups. For example, an AI system for skin cancer screening was found to be <Link href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2021/nov/09/ai-skin-cancer-diagnoses-risk-being-less-accurate-for-dark-skin-study" isExternal color="blue.500">less accurate on patients with darker skin</Link>, because most training images were of light-skinned individuals. The researchers who uncovered this warned that it could lead to missed melanomas in patients of color or unnecessary procedures due to false alarms. (<Link href="https://knightcolumbia.org/blog/a-safe-harbor-for-ai-evaluation-and-red-teaming#:~:text=While%20many%20types%20of%20testing,bias%2C%20copyright%2C%20and%20other%20issues" isExternal color="blue.500">Longpre et al., 2024</Link>) In healthcare AI, diverse red team input is literally life-saving: clinicians and data scientists from different regions can test whether an algorithm trained in, say, Europe works on Latin American or African patient data. Including these perspectives helps catch issues like diagnostic tools misreading certain genetic markers or medical devices that don't account for cultural differences in symptom reporting.
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    <Text fontWeight="bold">Cultural Mismatches & Fairness:</Text> AI systems often reflect the cultural context of their creators, which can cause problems when deployed globally. Generative AI models have been caught reinforcing stereotypes – with one study showing these models portray non-Western cultures "through an outsider's lens," (often oversimplifying or misrepresenting traditions. (<Link href="https://ist.psu.edu/news/non-western-cultures-misrepresented-harmed-by-generative-ai-researchers-say/" isExternal color="blue.500">Venkit et al. 2024</Link>) This is not only offensive but can also lead to poor user experiences (imagine a virtual assistant misunderstanding honorifics or social cues in Japan because it was designed in the U.S.). Inclusive development and red teaming inject local knowledge to prevent such cultural mismatches.
                  </ListItem>
                  <Text>

                    When AI is co-created and tested by people from different linguistic, ethnic, and social backgrounds, it performs better across the board. Inclusive red teaming doesn't just mitigate harm – it also uncovers new use cases and improvements. For instance, African NLP researchers have contributed novel data sets and tools for local languages, making AI more useful to millions and expanding its market (<Link href="https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2402.02680" isExternal color="blue.500">Manvi et al., 2024</Link>). The bottom line: diversity is a strength in AI development. It helps ensure AI systems respect differences in language, culture, and context, rather than imposing a uniform approach that might fail many users.
                  </Text>
                </UnorderedList>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h2" size="xl">
                  Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming
                </Heading>
                
                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Legal and Regulatory Barriers
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Many countries have unclear or restrictive laws around AI system testing. This creates legal uncertainty that discourages participation in red teaming efforts. Key issues include:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Computer misuse and cybersecurity laws that may criminalize certain testing approaches</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Intellectual property restrictions limiting access to model details</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Data protection regulations affecting testing data collection and sharing</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Export controls on AI technologies that prevent cross-border collaboration</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Resource and Infrastructure Gaps
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Many regions face significant resource constraints that limit their ability to participate in AI development and testing:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Limited access to computing infrastructure and high-performance hardware</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Insufficient funding for AI research and testing initiatives</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Lack of specialized training programs and educational resources</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Poor internet connectivity and digital infrastructure in some areas</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Knowledge and Expertise Barriers
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Technical expertise is often concentrated in a few global hubs, creating challenges for broader participation:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Limited access to advanced AI training and education</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Language barriers in technical documentation and research</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Brain drain of AI talent to major tech hubs</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Lack of local mentorship and professional development opportunities</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* Enabling Participation Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h2" size="xl">
                  Enabling Participation
                </Heading>
                
                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Legal and Policy Solutions
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Creating an enabling environment for global participation requires addressing legal barriers through:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Safe harbor provisions for legitimate AI testing activities</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Clear guidelines on permissible testing approaches</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>International frameworks for cross-border collaboration</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Standardized protocols for responsible disclosure</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Capacity Building Initiatives
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Supporting the development of local expertise and infrastructure through:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Regional AI research and testing centers</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Training programs and educational partnerships</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Funding for local AI safety initiatives</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Technical resource sharing programs</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Collaborative Networks
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Building networks to connect global participants:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>International research partnerships</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Mentorship programs connecting experts with emerging practitioners</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Knowledge sharing platforms and communities of practice</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Regular conferences and workshops focused on inclusive AI safety</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* Domain-Specific Governance Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h2" size="xl">
                  Domain-Specific Governance
                </Heading>
                
                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Healthcare AI
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Special considerations for AI systems in healthcare:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Patient data privacy and protection requirements</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Medical device regulations and safety standards</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Cultural sensitivity in healthcare delivery</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Access and equity considerations</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Financial Services
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Governance frameworks for AI in financial applications:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Fair lending and anti-discrimination requirements</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Risk management and system stability considerations</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Consumer protection measures</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Cross-border financial regulations</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Public Sector Applications
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Guidelines for government use of AI:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Transparency and accountability requirements</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Public consultation processes</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Impact assessments for vulnerable populations</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Democratic oversight mechanisms</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* Global Coordination Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h2" size="xl">
                  Global Coordination
                </Heading>
                
                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    International Frameworks
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Developing coordinated approaches to AI governance:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Multilateral agreements on AI safety standards</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Shared principles for responsible AI development</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Cross-border incident response protocols</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>International monitoring and enforcement mechanisms</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Regional Cooperation
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Building regional capacity and coordination:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Regional AI safety centers and networks</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Shared research and testing infrastructure</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Harmonized regulatory approaches</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Joint capacity building initiatives</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>

                <Box>
                  <Heading as="h3" size="md" mb={3}>
                    Stakeholder Engagement
                  </Heading>
                  <Text>
                    Ensuring inclusive participation in governance:
                  </Text>
                  <UnorderedList mt={2} spacing={2}>
                    <ListItem>Multi-stakeholder dialogue processes</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Civil society participation mechanisms</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Industry-government partnerships</ListItem>
                    <ListItem>Academic and research collaboration networks</ListItem>
                  </UnorderedList>
                </Box>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* Resources Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h3" size="lg" mb={4}>Resources</Heading>

                <Heading as="h4" size="md" mb={2}>Bias, Fairness & Safety Case Studies</Heading>
                <UnorderedList spacing={3}>
                  <ListItem>
                    Google Translate Gender Bias Overview (Stuyvesant Spectator): <Link href="https://stuyspec.com/article/the-bias-of-google-translate" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://stuyspec.com/article/the-bias-of-google-translate</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Apple Card Gender Bias Case (NYT Reference): <Link href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/10/business/Apple-credit-card-investigation.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/10/business/Apple-credit-card-investigation.html</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  {/* Add other relevant case studies here if available */}
                </UnorderedList>

                <Heading as="h4" size="md" mb={2}>Safe Harbor & Researcher Protection</Heading>
                <UnorderedList spacing={3}>
                  <ListItem>
                    Knight Institute – "A Safe Harbor for AI Red Teaming" (Nov 2023): <Link href="https://knightcolumbia.org/blog/a-safe-harbor-for-ai-evaluation-and-red-teaming" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://knightcolumbia.org/blog/a-safe-harbor-for-ai-evaluation-and-red-teaming</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Open Letter / Paper: A Safe Harbor for AI Evaluation and Red Teaming (OpenReview): <Link href="https://openreview.net/pdf?id=dLojMSgSFW" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://openreview.net/pdf?id=dLojMSgSFW</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    FAS Report: Safe Harbor for AI Researchers (2024): <Link href="https://fas.org/publication/safe-harbor-for-ai-researchers/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://fas.org/publication/safe-harbor-for-ai-researchers/</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                </UnorderedList>

                <Heading as="h4" size="md" mb={2}>Red Teaming Frameworks & Methodologies</Heading>
                <UnorderedList spacing={3}>
                  <ListItem>
                    MAIA: A comprehensive framework for Model Assessment, Improvement, and Assurance (arXiv): <Link href="https://arxiv.org/html/2406.11757v1" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://arxiv.org/html/2406.11757v1</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0): <Link href="https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    OpenAI's Approach to External Red Teaming: <Link href="http://cdn.openai.com/papers/openais-approach-to-external-red-teaming.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">http://cdn.openai.com/papers/openais-approach-to-external-red-teaming.pdf</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Microsoft: Lessons From Red Teaming 100 Generative AI Products (arXiv): <Link href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2501.07238" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://arxiv.org/abs/2501.07238</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    OWASP Top 10 for LLMs (Includes red teaming methodology discussion): <Link href="https://owasp.org/www-project-top-10-for-large-language-model-applications/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://owasp.org/www-project-top-10-for-large-language-model-applications/</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    MITRE: AI Red Teaming: Advancing Safe and Secure AI Systems (Policy Brief): <Link href="https://www.mitre.org/sites/default/files/2024-07/PR-24-01820-4-AI-Red-Teaming-Advancing-Safe-Secure-AI-Systems.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://www.mitre.org/sites/default/files/2024-07/PR-24-01820-4-AI-Red-Teaming-Advancing-Safe-Secure-AI-Systems.pdf</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                </UnorderedList>

                <Heading as="h4" size="md" mb={2}>Red Teaming Tools & Platforms</Heading>
                <UnorderedList spacing={3}>
                  <ListItem>
                    Awesome Red Teaming List (GitHub): <Link href="https://github.com/yeyintminthuhtut/Awesome-Red-Teaming" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://github.com/yeyintminthuhtut/Awesome-Red-Teaming</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Microsoft PyRIT (Python Risk Identification Toolkit): <Link href="https://github.com/Azure/PyRIT" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://github.com/Azure/PyRIT</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Garak (LLM Vulnerability Scanner): <Link href="https://github.com/leondz/garak" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://github.com/leondz/garak</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    IBM AI Fairness 360: <Link href="https://aif360.mybluemix.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://aif360.mybluemix.net/</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Linux Foundation ART (Adversarial Robustness Toolbox): <Link href="https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    AI Verify Foundation Moonshot: <Link href="https://github.com/aiverify-foundation/moonshot" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://github.com/aiverify-foundation/moonshot</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    Hugging Face Model Hub (Platform for accessing models): <Link href="https://huggingface.co/models" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://huggingface.co/models</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                  <ListItem>
                    TensorFlow Datasets (Platform for accessing datasets): <Link href="https://www.tensorflow.org/datasets" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" color="blue.500">https://www.tensorflow.org/datasets</Link>
                  </ListItem>
                </UnorderedList>
              </VStack>
            </TabPanel>

            {/* References Tab */}
            <TabPanel>
              <VStack spacing={6} align="stretch">
                <Heading as="h3" size="lg" mb={4}>References</Heading>
